Topic.Title: Clobbered and Bashed Trails

Message.Msg: Intel is clearly out of its comfort zone at the present time. Until Intel new CEO clearly articulate the company's new identity and vision, the stock INTC will only make small gains at best, assuming Haswell, Iris Pro, and clovertrail/baytrail etc all perform well in sales. The investment community needs to see the forest, not only the tress. Andy Grove rescued Intel from the Dram crisis in the mid-1080s, and gave Intel a clear new identify of becoming the world's greatest microprocessor designer. Intel has reaped huge benefits from Grove's repositioning for over 25 years, and now it is clearly no longer working in the post-PC era. What will Intel's new identify be? Can it compete effectively not as the top dog, but as a distant third in the mobile space? Can it succeed in its future initiatives without being a de facto monopolist? How quickly can Intel's senior management, engineers, as well as marketers adjust to the new mindset? Until some indications of answers are demonstrated, many (not all) investors will continue to see risks investing in this stock. The two new strategic directions mostly frequently mentioned - mobile and manufacturing - are all inherently associated with lower GM than what INTC was traditionally accustomed to - fairly or unfairly.

Message.Title: Anandtech reviews Iris Pro, concluding that "nVIDIA is fairly safe"
Message.Msg: A very extensive review. Below are concluding remarks: "Final Words For the past few years Intel has been threatening to make discrete GPUs obsolete with its march towards higher performing integrated GPUs. Given what we know about Iris Pro today, I'd say NVIDIA is fairly safe. The highest performing implementation of NVIDIA's GeForce GT 650M remains appreciably quicker than Iris Pro 5200 on average. Intel does catch up in some areas, but that's by no means the norm. NVIDIA's recently announced GT 750M should increase the margin a bit as well. Haswell doesn't pose any imminent threat to NVIDIA's position in traditional gaming notebooks. OpenCL performance is excellent, which is surprising given how little public attention Intel has given to the standard from a GPU perspective. ...... anandtechDOTcom/show/6993/intel-iris-pro-5200-graphics-review-core-i74950hq-tested/20

Topic.Title: Anandtech reviews Iris Pro, concluding that "nVIDIA is fairly safe"

Message.Msg: For gaming, absolutely - there's really no way that I would have expected Iris Pro to displace dGPUs for gamers. But take a look at the level of GPGPU compute Intel is packing onto this thing - it's enormous!

Message.Title: "New AMD-Based Tablet PC Processor Wins 2013 "Best Choice of COMPUTEX TAIPEI" Award"
Message.Msg: "New AMD-Based Tablet PC Processor Wins 2013 "Best Choice of COMPUTEX TAIPEI" Award" "Elite Mobility SoC for Tablets and Hybrids, Codenamed "Temash," Recognized for Unique Achievements in Compute Power and Extended Battery Life" "SUNNYVALE, CA--(Marketwired - May 28, 2013) - AMD (NYSE: AMD) today announced its lowest-power accelerated processing unit (APU) for tablet, hybrid and clamshell notebook PCs is the winner of the 2013 Best Choice of COMPUTEX TAIPEI award, the third consecutive win for AMD. The award is given by the Taipei Computer Association, a driving force behind the annual event and the leading technology organization in the country. "We are very excited to receive this important award from the Taipei Computer Association for the third consecutive year, each year for our innovation in APUs," said Lisa Su, senior vice president and general manager, Global Business Units at AMD. "It's been our goal to deliver a more complete, full-featured experience on tablet and hybrid PCs, and we've been successful with our third generation A-Series APUs. It's a great honor to be recognized for our innovation and technology leadership at this prestigious event." " Source: amdDOTcom

Topic.Title: Clobbered and Bashed Trails

Message.Msg: Don't get too hung up on performance, Clovertrail and Clovertrail+ are about to become big sales successes as they offer very competitive performance/power/price numbers contrary to all the x86 price/power myths put about by competitors so they are going into many designs. These chips will live much longer than Tegra 3 while Tegra 1 and 2 are long gone already. The Tegra concept is still a stop/start WIP rather than a proven viable long term business model. That may change with T4/5/6 etc but that is the way it is now and you can't say you were not warned by me at the time ( 2 years ago) about all the tough competition it would face.

Nvidia has NOT launched a Tegra 4 part to date so no OEM can sell Tegra 4 parts before Nvidia launches Tegra 4 parts. Third, After AMD announced Jaguar APU SoC parts were shipping for revenue (sold) and launched they allowed Sony and Microsoft to announce major products based on Jaguar cores. So for the logically slow, Nvidia has to first launch a product or all you are doing is wishing they would launch a product so OEMs can sell something with Tegra 4 inside. AMD launched Jaguar, OEMs and ODMs announced products using Jaguar and products are for sale today. Try and keep up, can you but a Tegra 4 product today? If you can't buy a Tegra 4 product today its BS, especially since Nvidia has not launched Tegra 4. I can buy a Jaguar product today as can all the sites benchmarking Jaguar systems. IMHO ,

Message.Title: "Future Windows 8.1 tablets to tap Qualcomm chip"
Message.Msg: "Future Windows 8.1 tablets to tap Qualcomm chip" "Qualcomm's Snapdragon 800 silicon is expected to power upcoming Windows RT tablets. by Brooke Crothers June 3, 2013 7:40 PM PDT The next round of Windows 8.1 RT tablets will be supported by Qualcomm's Snapdragon 800, the chipmaker announced Monday. Could it be destined for a future Surface tablet? That's not clear yet but Qualcomm hints at future RT products with its silicon. "Qualcomm continues to build on its relationship with Microsoft by helping to launch and optimize the newest build of Windows for Snapdragon, Windows 8.1 RT," the chip supplier said. The statement continued. "The next processor to be featured in upcoming Windows 8.1 RT computers will be the Qualcomm Snapdragon 800." Meet the Snapdragon 800: Bound for Windows 8.1 RT tablets Quad-core: Supports up to four cores, 2.2GHz per core. USB 3.0: USB 3.0 is coming to more RT devices. 4G/LTE: 3G/4G/LTE is integrated, Qualcomm's strength is integration of 3G/4G into its silicon. Very-high-resolution displays: Supports up to 2,560x2,048 resolution. And Microsoft seems keen on the silicon. "We are excited [about]...the next iteration of Windows RT 8.1 [and] their new Snapdragon 800 processors," Mike Anguilo, Corporate Vice President at Microsoft, said in a statement. His statement also mentions the "numerous advantages of these new processors" including integrated 4G/LTE." Source: CNET

Topic.Title: "Future Windows 8.1 tablets to tap Qualcomm chip"

Message.Msg: Qualcomm and Microsoft are both talking up Windows RT 8.1 and Snapdragon 800. You won't find a certain DOA part mentioned in the entire article so I won't mention it here. lol imho
